subject: Re: [junit] A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: ... That s true for logs like server logs that collect data from the outside . It doesn t make any sense to me for test logs, where no outside influences
messageBody:
On Monday 09 June 2008 22:57, Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> It's the definition of a log: most of the time, you don't need it,
> but it's handy if you need to double check something after your tests
> have run.

That's true for logs like server logs that collect data from "the
outside". It doesn't make any sense to me for test logs, where no
"outside" influences the result. Unless of course you don't trust your
test framework.

> Not just for BDD, not sure why you want to single this out.

For its documention and communication purposes. I understand that a list
of tests (or a list of "the program should") is helpful to show to the
customer. But such a list at the unit test level is probably overkill.

> I know of organizations that commit all the test results (HTML and
> others) to databases every day so they can run long-term statistics
> and various other metrics over the course of time.

Yes. I also know people who think waterfall is a good idea.

Robert
